elements.content: Controlled self-assembly of the inorganic–organic hybrid compounds based on polyoxometalates (POMs) is hampered by the wide range of oxo and hydroxo units on the peripheries of POMs and many chemical parameters. In this work, aiming to understand the pH value influence on the POM/Ag/trz assembly (trz = 1,2,3-triazole), two new hybrid compounds based on POMs combining with metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), H­[Ag27(trz)16(H2O)4]­[(AsW12O40)2] (1), and [Ag15(trz)8]­[AsW12O40] (2), were isolated under different pH value. The structural analysis reveals that the [Ag7(trz)4]3+ subunits and Keggin-type arsenotungstate are assembled into a complicated three-dimensional framework containing two distinct types of channels in compound 1. And the [Ag5(trz)4]+ subunits and Keggin-type arsenotungstate are assembled into a three-dimensional framework containing the single channel under the aid of Ag–Ag bonds in compound 2. In addition, compounds 1 and 2 were employed as anode materials of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and exhibited the promising electrochemical performances.

elements.content: By controlling the pH value, two new hybrid compounds based on POM/Ag/trz were successfully obtained, which exhibits the high discharge capacity as anode materials in LIBs due to the stable charge transmission channels provided by the different three-dimensional frameworks.

elements.content: Studies about metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) composed of metal nodes and organic linkers have caused vast attention originating from large internal surfaces areas, high tunability and designability, as well as their potential applications, such as catalysis, gas storage, separation, sensor, and proton conduction. Polyoxometalates (POMs) with abundant topologies and remarkable properties have been proved to be a class of excellent building blocks to fabricate extended multifunctional POM-based MOFs (POMOFs). But the only fly in the ointment is that the controlled self-assembly of POMOFs is hampered by the randomicity of the coordination among POMs, metal nodes and organic molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Studies about metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) composed of metal nodes and organic linkers have caused vast attention originating from large internal surfaces areas, high tunability and designability, as well as their potential applications, such as catalysis, gas storage, separation, sensor, and proton conduction. Polyoxometalates (POMs) with abundant topologies and remarkable properties have been proved to be a class of excellent building blocks to fabricate extended multifunctional POM-based MOFs (POMOFs). But the only fly in the ointment is that the controlled self-assembly of POMOFs is hampered by the randomicity of the coordination among POMs, metal nodes and organic molecules.

elements.content: Historically, many fascinating MOFs, such as catenane, helix, nanocage, and metal–carbene frameworks (MCFs), have been successfully fabricated based on the containing N heterocyclic organic molecules (1,2,3-triazole,1,2,4-triazole,1,2,3,4-tetrazole, etc.). And in the ongoing process, POMs as template/building blocks were introduced into MOFs generating multifarious POMOFs, for example, POM-based catenane, POM-based helices, POM-based metallacalixarene, and POM-based MCFs. To the best of our knowledge on Ag-trz-based POMOFs, besides a main factor of the suitable combination, other factors, such as solvent, pH value, temperature, also significantly affect the formation of POMOFs. To investigate the pH value influence on the structures of Ag-trz-based POMOFs, herein, we successfully isolated two new POMOF compounds, H­[Ag27(trz)16(H2O)4]­[(AsW12O40)2] (1), and [Ag15(trz)8]­[AsW12O40] (2), under the different pH value. Moreover, graphite, as a commercial lithium-ion battery (LIBs) anode, suffers from lower theoretical capacity of 372 mAh g–1, thus developing new alternative anode materials with high capacities and stable cycle performances for LIBs need to be explored. Note that POMs with the superiority of reversible redox behavior and electron storage functions are expected to be promising candidates as anode materials of LIBs. A fact is that [PMo12O40]3– as the cathode of LIBs exhibited a higher capacity and a reversible 24-electons redox. Based on the fascinating structural and excellent electrochemical performance of POMs, MOFs, and in particular POMOFs as electrode materials, the new compounds as anode materials in LIBs were explored in the work, respectively.

elements.content: All chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without purification. C, H, and N analyses were measured using a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN analyzer. FTIR was recorded on the Alpha Centaurt FT-IR spectrometer with a KBr pellet between 400 and 4000 cm–1. PXRD data were collected on a Rigaku D/MAX 2500 V diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The working electrode for the electrochemical measurements was prepared by casting a slurry of the compound 1/2 (2 mg), super-P carbon (0.57 mg), and PVDF (0.28 mg) on pure Cu foil. Then Cu foil was dried at 50 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. The loading electroactive mass on the electrode is ∼2 mg cm–2. The testing coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox, in which the pure Li foil was employed as the counter electrode, and 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylenecarbonate/diethylcarbonate 1:1­(v/v) was used as the electrolyte. Discharging/charging measurements were carried out using a LAND 2001A Battery Tester from 0.01 to 3.00 V. CV measurements were performed with the CHI750D electrochemical workstation.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without purification. C, H, and N analyses were measured using a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN analyzer. FTIR was recorded on the Alpha Centaurt FT-IR spectrometer with a KBr pellet between 400 and 4000 cm-1. PXRD data were collected on a Rigaku D/MAX 2500 V diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The working electrode for the electrochemical measurements was prepared by casting a slurry of the compound 1/2 (2 mg), super-P carbon (0.57 mg), and PVDF (0.28 mg) on pure Cu foil. Then Cu foil was dried at 50 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven. The loading electroactive mass on the electrode is ~2 mg cm-2. The testing coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox, in which the pure Li foil was employed as the counter electrode, and 1.0 M LiPF6 in ethylenecarbonate/diethylcarbonate 1:1(v/v) was used as the electrolyte. Discharging/charging measurements were carried out using a LAND 2001A Battery Tester from 0.01 to 3.00 V. CV measurements were performed with the CHI750D electrochemical workstation.

elements.content: A mixture of Na3AsW12O40 (300 mg, 0.10 mmol), AgNO3 (300 mg, 1.77 mmol), 1,2,3trz (30 mg, 0.43 mmol), NH4VO3 (36 mg, 0.31 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred for 60 min, then pH was adjusted to ca. 1.75 with 1 mol L–1 HCl solution. Finally, the mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined container and heated at 170 °C for 5 d. After slowly cooling to room temperature, reddish brown block crystals of 1 were collected and washed and air-dried (42% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C32H41N48Ag27As2W24O84 (9916.4): C 3.87%, H 0.41%, N 6.77%; Found: C 3.88%, H 0.52%, N 6.63%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H[Ag27(trz)16(H2O)4][(AsW12O40)2] (1)

A mixture of Na3AsW12O40 (300 mg, 0.10 mmol), AgNO3 (300 mg, 1.77 mmol), 1,2,3trz (30 mg, 0.43 mmol), NH4VO3 (36 mg, 0.31 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred for 60 min, then pH was adjusted to ca. 1.75 with 1 mol L-1 HCl solution. Finally, the mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined container and heated at 170 °C for 5 d. After slowly cooling to room temperature, reddish brown block crystals of 1 were collected and washed and air-dried (42% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C32H41N48Ag27As2W24O84 (9916.4): C 3.87%, H 0.41%, N 6.77%; Found: C 3.88%, H 0.52%, N 6.63%.

elements.content: The preparation of compound 2 was similar to compound 1, except for pH value (ca. 5.60 with 1 M NaOH solution). Red block crystals were collected and washed and air-dried (35% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calc. for C16H16N24Ag15AsW12O40 (5083.47): C 3.77%, H 0.31%, N 6.61%; Found: C 3.69%, H 0.49%, N 6.57%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ag15(trz)8][AsW12O40] (2)

The preparation of compound 2 was similar to compound 1, except for pH value (ca. 5.60 with 1 M NaOH solution). Red block crystals were collected and washed and air-dried (35% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calc. for C16H16N24Ag15AsW12O40 (5083.47): C 3.77%, H 0.31%, N 6.61%; Found: C 3.69%, H 0.49%, N 6.57%.

elements.content: The crystal data for compounds 1 and 2 were obtained on the Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ= 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. The programs of WINGX and SHELXTL were used for the structural solution and refined. Some NPD and ADP atoms were refined by the ISOR command. Selected crystal data and refinement results are provided in . CCDC 1543871 for 1 and 1585189 for 2. Selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Table S1 for 1 and Table S2 for 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The crystal data for compounds 1 and 2 were obtained on the Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ= 0.71073 Å) at 296 K. The programs of WINGX and SHELXTL were used for the structural solution and refined. Some NPD and ADP atoms were refined by the ISOR command. Selected crystal data and refinement results are provided in . CCDC 1543871 for 1 and 1585189 for 2. Selected bond lengths and angles are shown in Table S1 for 1 and Table S2 for 2.

X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that the fundamental unit of compound 1 is composed of two [AsW12O40]6– polyoxoanion (abbreviated as AsW12), twenty-seven Ag ions, 16 trz ligands, and four coordinated water, a. Fourteen independent Ag ions adopt five kinds of coordination modes, Figure S1a: Ag1 shows “seesaw” geometry completed by N atoms (N15 and N27) and O atoms from AsW12 clusters; Ag2, Ag3, Ag4, Ag8, Ag9, Ag11, and Ag13 all exhibit “T-shaped” coordination geometry defined by two N atoms and one O atom, while Ag12 possesses distorted triangle geometry defined by one N atom (N4), one μ2-O atom (O38) and one water molecule (O1W); Ag5, Ag6 and Ag10 all adopt “chain-like” geometry by two N atoms from the adjacent trz molecules; Ag7 coordinates with one N atom, two μ2-oxygen and one terminal oxygen and one water molecule (O2W); Ag14 links with one N atom, three μ2-O atoms and one terminal oxygen. As a consequence, the AsW12 clusters as 15-coordinated inorganic ligands connect with 13 Ag ions (b) dominating and stabilizing the whole structure of compound 1, in which AsW12 clusters exhibits the highest odd coordination of Keggin-type POMs to date, to the best of our knowledge. The bond distances are in the normal range of 2.312–2.483 Å for Ag–O bonds and 2.024–2.306 Å for Ag–N bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that the fundamental unit of compound 1 is composed of two [AsW12O40]6- polyoxoanion (abbreviated as AsW12), twenty-seven Ag ions, 16 trz ligands, and four coordinated water, a. Fourteen independent Ag ions adopt five kinds of coordination modes, Figure S1a: Ag1 shows "seesaw" geometry completed by N atoms (N15 and N27) and O atoms from AsW12 clusters; Ag2, Ag3, Ag4, Ag8, Ag9, Ag11, and Ag13 all exhibit "T-shaped" coordination geometry defined by two N atoms and one O atom, while Ag12 possesses distorted triangle geometry defined by one N atom (N4), one μ2-O atom (O38) and one water molecule (O1W); Ag5, Ag6 and Ag10 all adopt "chain-like" geometry by two N atoms from the adjacent trz molecules; Ag7 coordinates with one N atom, two μ2-oxygen and one terminal oxygen and one water molecule (O2W); Ag14 links with one N atom, three μ2-O atoms and one terminal oxygen. As a consequence, the AsW12 clusters as 15-coordinated inorganic ligands connect with 13 Ag ions (b) dominating and stabilizing the whole structure of compound 1, in which AsW12 clusters exhibits the highest odd coordination of Keggin-type POMs to date, to the best of our knowledge. The bond distances are in the normal range of 2.312-2.483 Å for Ag-O bonds and 2.024-2.306 Å for Ag-N bonds.

elements.content: As shown in , compound 1 possesses a complicated three-dimensional structure. Without regard for AsW12 polyoxoanions, four trz ligands with seven Ag ions construct two types of the similar motifs [Ag7(trz)4]3+ named as subunit A (Ag2, Ag4, Ag7, Ag8, Ag9, Ag12, and Ag13) and subunit B (Ag1, Ag3, Ag5, Ag6, Ag10, Ag11, and Ag14). Then subunits B interconnect through Ag10 ions forming discrete [Ag13(trz)8]5+ subunits C (c). On the other hand, AsW12 polyoxoanions connect alternately with Ag1 and Ag7 ions generating POM-Ag chain (Figure S1b), then adjacent POM-Ag chains are connected by subunits A and B obtaining two-dimensional layer in a and S2a. It should be noted that the twisted subunits C intersperse in the quadrangular holes. Finally neighboring 2D layers are connected together constructing the three-dimensional architecture by sharing O19, O20, O27, Ag2, Ag8 and Ag3 atoms (b and Figure S2b). For understanding the complicated structure, the topology analysis is used to predigest the structure of compound 1, in which Ag2, Ag3, and Ag8 act as 2-connected nodes, Ag5 as 3-connected nodes, Ag4 and Ag10 as 4-connected nodes, while the AsW12 clusters act as 9-connected nodes. Then the complicated 3D structure can be predigested as a (2, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 9)-connected net with the topology symbol of {312·46·54}2 {310·46·53·62} {38·45·5} {36·45·5·6}2 {32·82·92} in Figure S2b. It is interesting that two types of channel (diamonded channel A and rectangular channel B) can be easily perceived from c, d.

elements.content: The fundamental unit of compound 2 consists of one AsW12 polyoxoanion, eight trz molecules and 15 Ag ions, Figure S3a. There are 15 independent Ag ions (Ag1 to Ag15) with seven types of coordination modes, Figure S3b. Specifically speaking, five Ag atoms (Ag1, Ag2, Ag5, Ag11, and Ag13) adopt “T-type” coordination geometry completed by two N atoms and one Ag ions; three Ag atoms (Ag3, Ag7 and Ag9) adopt linear coordination mode with two N atoms; both Ag4 and Ag10 adopt distorted bipyramid geometry completed by other three Ag atoms and two N atoms; both Ag6 and Ag8 exhibit four-coordinated “see-saw” coordination geometry with other two Ag atoms and two N atoms; Ag12 and Ag 14 links with other six atoms and five Ag atoms, respectively. The remaining Ag15 exhibits screwy pyramidal geometry defined by five O atoms from the AsW12 polyoxoanions. The bond distances are in the normal range of 2.045–2.248 Å for Ag–N bonds, and 2.691–3.282 Å for Ag–Ag bonds. As a consequence, the AsW12 clusters as eight-coordinated inorganic ligands connect with four Ag ions.
elements.clean_text: The fundamental unit of compound 2 consists of one AsW12 polyoxoanion, eight trz molecules and 15 Ag ions, Figure S3a. There are 15 independent Ag ions (Ag1 to Ag15) with seven types of coordination modes, Figure S3b. Specifically speaking, five Ag atoms (Ag1, Ag2, Ag5, Ag11, and Ag13) adopt "T-type" coordination geometry completed by two N atoms and one Ag ions; three Ag atoms (Ag3, Ag7 and Ag9) adopt linear coordination mode with two N atoms; both Ag4 and Ag10 adopt distorted bipyramid geometry completed by other three Ag atoms and two N atoms; both Ag6 and Ag8 exhibit four-coordinated "see-saw" coordination geometry with other two Ag atoms and two N atoms; Ag12 and Ag 14 links with other six atoms and five Ag atoms, respectively. The remaining Ag15 exhibits screwy pyramidal geometry defined by five O atoms from the AsW12 polyoxoanions. The bond distances are in the normal range of 2.045-2.248 Å for Ag-N bonds, and 2.691-3.282 Å for Ag-Ag bonds. As a consequence, the AsW12 clusters as eight-coordinated inorganic ligands connect with four Ag ions.

elements.content: Similar to compound 1, each trz offers three N donors to connect with three Ag ions forming two types of metal–organic subunits ([Ag5(trz)4]+) in compound 2, namely, subunit A′ (Ag4, Ag6, Ag7, Ag9, and Ag13) and B′ (Ag1, Ag2, Ag3, Ag5, and Ag10), a. Then subunits A′ and B′ are linked alternately by sharing Ag11 and Ag8 constituting a wavy single chain, b. It is important to point out that Ag–Ag bonds are widely present and dominate the formation of compound 2 (), including Ag6–Ag14, Ag14–Ag10, Ag14–Ag11, Ag2–Ag12, Ag12–Ag4, and Ag12–Ag8 in the single chain. Further, the adjacent single chains are fused together via Ag8–Ag6 bonds as “cross bars” leading to a ladder-like double chain, which can be realized as [Ag26(trz)16]10+ dimers (Figure S4a) interconnected by sharing Ag8 and Ag12, c. Finally, the adjacent ladder-like double chains are linked further through Ag–Ag bonds (Ag1–Ag12, Ag5–Ag12, Ag12–Ag10, Ag10–Ag4, Ag4–Ag14, and Ag14–Ag13) fabricating two-dimensional layer (d).

Then subunits A' and B' are linked alternately by sharing Ag11 and Ag8 constituting a wavy single chain, b. It is important to point out that Ag-Ag bonds are widely present and dominate the formation of compound 2 (), including Ag6-Ag14, Ag14-Ag10, Ag14-Ag11, Ag2-Ag12, Ag12-Ag4, and Ag12-Ag8 in the single chain. Further, the adjacent single chains are fused together via Ag8-Ag6 bonds as "cross bars" leading to a ladder-like double chain, which can be realized as [Ag26(trz)16]10+ dimers (Figure S4a) interconnected by sharing Ag8 and Ag12, c. Finally, the adjacent ladder-like double chains are linked further through Ag-Ag bonds (Ag1-Ag12, Ag5-Ag12, Ag12-Ag10, Ag10-Ag4, Ag4-Ag14, and Ag14-Ag13) fabricating two-dimensional layer (d).

elements.content: Unambiguously, pH values in the Ag-trz based POMOFs are a significant influencing factor on structures of compounds (1.75 for 1, 5.60 for 2). The fact indicates that the assembly of compounds 1 and 2 is pH-dependent. More specifically, the silver ion does not hydrolyze at higher acidity conditions, which means that Ag ions are sufficient to coordinate with trz and POMs. On the contrary, with the acidity continuous decreasing, the coordination chances among Ag, trz, and POMs will be decreased, which is not conducive to the formation of high-coordination POMs. As a result, each AsW12 polyoxoanion coordinate with 13 Ag ions in compound 1, but four Ag ions in 2. Similar results can be also found in other POMOFs. On the other hand, the orbital energy of 5p orbital are close to that of 4d orbital in adjacent Ag ions, thus Ag ions tend to form the weak interactions, called “argentophilic interaction”. Precisely because the free Ag ions surrounding the POMs in compound 2 are geometrically close, more Ag–Ag bonds are formed, as shown in . Although [Ag n (trz) m ] subunits as channel building block are all formed by the same coordination modes of trz during the assembling process of compounds 1 and 2, the unit length are only 7.80 and 8.10 Å in compound 1, and 23.81 Å in compound 2 due to the existence of Ag–Ag bonds. As a result, two types of channels with smaller dimension are generated in 1, whereas one larger dimensional channel is formed in 2.
elements.clean_text:
pH Influence on the Ag-trz-Based POMOF Structures

Unambiguously, pH values in the Ag-trz based POMOFs are a significant influencing factor on structures of compounds (1.75 for 1, 5.60 for 2). The fact indicates that the assembly of compounds 1 and 2 is pH-dependent. More specifically, the silver ion does not hydrolyze at higher acidity conditions, which means that Ag ions are sufficient to coordinate with trz and POMs. On the contrary, with the acidity continuous decreasing, the coordination chances among Ag, trz, and POMs will be decreased, which is not conducive to the formation of high-coordination POMs. As a result, each AsW12 polyoxoanion coordinate with 13 Ag ions in compound 1, but four Ag ions in 2. Similar results can be also found in other POMOFs. On the other hand, the orbital energy of 5p orbital are close to that of 4d orbital in adjacent Ag ions, thus Ag ions tend to form the weak interactions, called "argentophilic interaction". Precisely because the free Ag ions surrounding the POMs in compound 2 are geometrically close, more Ag-Ag bonds are formed, as shown in . Although [Ag n (trz) m ] subunits as channel building block are all formed by the same coordination modes of trz during the assembling process of compounds 1 and 2, the unit length are only 7.80 and 8.10 Å in compound 1, and 23.81 Å in compound 2 due to the existence of Ag-Ag bonds. As a result, two types of channels with smaller dimension are generated in 1, whereas one larger dimensional channel is formed in 2.

elements.content: The IR spectra (Figure S5) exhibit the characteristic peaks of AsW12 polyoxoanion at 981, 898, and 773 cm–1 for compound 1, 962, 898, 776, and 660 cm–1 for compound 2, which are attributed to the νas (As–O), νas (Ot–W), and νas (W–Ob/c–W) vibrations. The peak bonds in the region of 1626–1100 cm–1 can be ascribed as to the stretching vibrations of trz. PXRD was applied to investigate the purity of compounds, Figure S6. The diffraction peaks of the experimental patterns are almost identical to that of simulated patterns, only a little difference about reflection intensities, confirming the purity of new compounds. In addition, the XPS (Figure S7) shows two overlapping peaks at 35.17 and 37.26 eV for 1 and 34.54 and 36.58 eV for 2, which are attributed to WV and WVI, respectively. The analysis result indicates that three out of 12 W for 1 and four out of 12 W for 2 are +5 oxidation states.
elements.clean_text:
IR, XPS, and XRPD Characterization

The IR spectra (Figure S5) exhibit the characteristic peaks of AsW12 polyoxoanion at 981, 898, and 773 cm-1 for compound 1, 962, 898, 776, and 660 cm-1 for compound 2, which are attributed to the νas (As-O), νas (Ot-W), and νas (W-Ob/c-W) vibrations. The peak bonds in the region of 1626-1100 cm-1 can be ascribed as to the stretching vibrations of trz. PXRD was applied to investigate the purity of compounds, Figure S6. The diffraction peaks of the experimental patterns are almost identical to that of simulated patterns, only a little difference about reflection intensities, confirming the purity of new compounds. In addition, the XPS (Figure S7) shows two overlapping peaks at 35.17 and 37.26 eV for 1 and 34.54 and 36.58 eV for 2, which are attributed to WV and WVI, respectively. The analysis result indicates that three out of 12 W for 1 and four out of 12 W for 2 are +5 oxidation states.

elements.content: On the basis of the promising features of compounds 1 and 2 reported in the work, their electrochemical performances as anode materials for LIBs were investigated in detail. shows the galvanostatic discharging/charging curves of compounds at a current density of 100 mA g–1, and the first discharge capacities of compounds 1 and 2 were 1208 and 1543 mAh g–1, respectively, and the second discharge capacities decrease to 735 mAh g–1 for compound 1 and 848 mAh g–1 for compound 2. The irreversible capacities loss is largely ascribed to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. To understand the influence of the conjugation of POMs and Ag-trz complexes on the battery performance, we also tested the electrochemical properties of the (NBu4)3[AsW12O40] as anode materials for LIBs under the identical conditions. And there is a remarkable reduction at the corresponding initial discharge capacities (588 mAh g–1 at the first cycle and 246 mAh g–1 at the second cycle), indicating that AsW12@Ag-trz hybrids are conducive to improving LIBs capacity than that of single component. After a dramatic initial drop, the cycling capacity maintains the levels of ca. 430 mAh g–1 for 100 cycles for 1 (capacity retention of 35.6%) and 480 mAh g–1 for 2 (capacity retention of 31.1%). For (NBu4)3[AsW12O40], the capacity changes to 80 mAh g–1 (capacity retention of 13.6%) after the same 100 cycles. This superior may be attributed to the stabilized crystal structures and the synergistic effects of AsW12 polyoxoanions and Ag-trz complexes. It can be also concluded that the channels facilitate the faster electrochemical insertion/extraction of Li+ ions, leading to a better capacity performances of compound 2. Moreover, the first cycle Coulombic efficiencies (CE) are only 59% for 1 and 52% for 2, maybe due to the electrolyte decomposition and the other side-reaction. But the Coulombic efficiencies of 1 as well as 2 all reach a plateau at ca. 99% after 30 cycles, suggesting their commendable cycling reversibility.
elements.clean_text:
Battery Performance

On the basis of the promising features of compounds 1 and 2 reported in the work, their electrochemical performances as anode materials for LIBs were investigated in detail.  shows the galvanostatic discharging/charging curves of compounds at a current density of 100 mA g-1, and the first discharge capacities of compounds 1 and 2 were 1208 and 1543 mAh g-1, respectively, and the second discharge capacities decrease to 735 mAh g-1 for compound 1 and 848 mAh g-1 for compound 2. The irreversible capacities loss is largely ascribed to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. To understand the influence of the conjugation of POMs and Ag-trz complexes on the battery performance, we also tested the electrochemical properties of the (NBu4)3[AsW12O40] as anode materials for LIBs under the identical conditions. And there is a remarkable reduction at the corresponding initial discharge capacities (588 mAh g-1 at the first cycle and 246 mAh g-1 at the second cycle), indicating that AsW12@Ag-trz hybrids are conducive to improving LIBs capacity than that of single component. After a dramatic initial drop, the cycling capacity maintains the levels of ca. 430 mAh g-1 for 100 cycles for 1 (capacity retention of 35.6%) and 480 mAh g-1 for 2 (capacity retention of 31.1%). For (NBu4)3[AsW12O40], the capacity changes to 80 mAh g-1 (capacity retention of 13.6%) after the same 100 cycles. This superior may be attributed to the stabilized crystal structures and the synergistic effects of AsW12 polyoxoanions and Ag-trz complexes. It can be also concluded that the channels facilitate the faster electrochemical insertion/extraction of Li+ ions, leading to a better capacity performances of compound 2. Moreover, the first cycle Coulombic efficiencies (CE) are only 59% for 1 and 52% for 2, maybe due to the electrolyte decomposition and the other side-reaction. But the Coulombic efficiencies of 1 as well as 2 all reach a plateau at ca. 99% after 30 cycles, suggesting their commendable cycling reversibility.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammetry (CV) of 1 and 2 were tested at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s–1, a, b. An irreversible reduction peak ca. 0.7 V reflects the formation of SEI films in the first cycle, due to the inserting Li+ into the POMOFs, but the reduction peak disappears in the following cycles. Because excellent rate performance and cycling stability of the electrode are key aspects for evaluating practical applications of LIBs. So the rate performances of 1 and 2 have been tested at the current densities of 100, 200, 500, and 1000 mA g–1, respectively. As shown in c, the reversible capacities at 100 mA g–1 are 748 mAh g–1 for 1 and 2 for 873 mAh g–1 after an initial drop, respectively. When increasing current to 1000 mA g–1, the capacities of 411 mAh g–1 for 1 and 579 mAh g–1 for 2 were maintained. Nevertheless, when reducing current back to 100 mA g–1, an original capacity is quickly recovered, suggesting the reversibility of 1 and 2. By comparison, the capacity of the (NBu4)3[AsW12O40] anode is much lower than that of compounds 1 and 2 at each according current, which further substantiates the advantage to improve the capacity performance and cycling stability of LIBs using compounds 1 and 2 as anodes of LIBs. In addition, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out to evaluate the electrochemical process of 1 and 2 anodes, and the EIS data were analyzed by employing the equivalent circuit model (d). Re represents the electrolyte resistance, and R f and R ct represent SEI film and the charge transfer resistance, respectively. Z w is the Warburg impedance, and CPEf and CPEct are associated with the interfacial resistance. It can be observed that the values of Re and R ct are 12.1 and 165.3 Ω for 1, 13.9 and 52.7 Ω for 2, which indicates that the reported compounds in the work are favorable to charge transfer and the Li+ insertion/extraction.

elements.content: Two novel Ag-trz and AsW12 cluster-based compounds with different channels were successfully isolated through self-assembly, in which the pH dominates the structural formation of the resultant compounds. The successful isolation of compounds further clarifies the impact factors for the control assembly of POMOFs. It should be determined that the “argentophilic interaction” can dominate the fabrication of the new POMOFs. And, depending on the stabilized crystal structures and the synergistic effects, compounds 1 and 2 exhibit the higher first discharging capacity together with good stable performances as anode materials of LIBs. The present result indicates that compounds 1 and 2 can be favorable to charge transmission during the discharge/charge process. More efforts about new POMOFs need to be done.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two novel Ag-trz and AsW12 cluster-based compounds with different channels were successfully isolated through self-assembly, in which the pH dominates the structural formation of the resultant compounds. The successful isolation of compounds further clarifies the impact factors for the control assembly of POMOFs. It should be determined that the "argentophilic interaction" can dominate the fabrication of the new POMOFs. And, depending on the stabilized crystal structures and the synergistic effects, compounds 1 and 2 exhibit the higher first discharging capacity together with good stable performances as anode materials of LIBs. The present result indicates that compounds 1 and 2 can be favorable to charge transmission during the discharge/charge process. More efforts about new POMOFs need to be done.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Na3AsW12O40 (300 mg, 0.10 mmol), AgNO3 (300 mg, 1.77 mmol), 1,2,3trz (30 mg, 0.43 mmol), NH4VO3 (36 mg, 0.31 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred for 60 min, then pH was adjusted to ca. 1.75 with 1 mol L–1 HCl solution. Finally, the mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined container and heated at 170 °C for 5 d. After slowly cooling to room temperature, reddish brown block crystals of 1 were collected and washed and air-dried (42% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C32H41N48Ag27As2W24O84 (9916.4): C 3.87%, H 0.41%, N 6.77%; Found: C 3.88%, H 0.52%, N 6.63%.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>15</sub>(trz)<sub>8</sub>]­[AsW<sub>12</sub>O<sub>40</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

The preparation of compound 2 was similar to compound 1, except for pH value (ca. 5.60 with 1 M NaOH solution). Red block crystals were collected and washed and air-dried (35% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calc. for C16H16N24Ag15AsW12O40 (5083.47): C 3.77%, H 0.31%, N 6.61%; Found: C 3.69%, H 0.49%, N 6.57%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of H[Ag27(trz)16(H2O)4][(AsW12O40)2] (1)

A mixture of Na3AsW12O40 (300 mg, 0.10 mmol), AgNO3 (300 mg, 1.77 mmol), 1,2,3trz (30 mg, 0.43 mmol), NH4VO3 (36 mg, 0.31 mmol), and water (15 mL) was stirred for 60 min, then pH was adjusted to ca. 1.75 with 1 mol L-1 HCl solution. Finally, the mixture was sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined container and heated at 170 °C for 5 d. After slowly cooling to room temperature, reddish brown block crystals of 1 were collected and washed and air-dried (42% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C32H41N48Ag27As2W24O84 (9916.4): C 3.87%, H 0.41%, N 6.77%; Found: C 3.88%, H 0.52%, N 6.63%.

Synthesis of [Ag15(trz)8][AsW12O40] (2)

The preparation of compound 2 was similar to compound 1, except for pH value (ca. 5.60 with 1 M NaOH solution). Red block crystals were collected and washed and air-dried (35% yield based on Ag). Anal. Calc. for C16H16N24Ag15AsW12O40 (5083.47): C 3.77%, H 0.31%, N 6.61%; Found: C 3.69%, H 0.49%, N 6.57%.

cln_elements.content: On the basis of the promising features of compounds 1 and 2 reported in the work, their electrochemical performances as anode materials for LIBs were investigated in detail. shows the galvanostatic discharging/charging curves of compounds at a current density of 100 mA g–1, and the first discharge capacities of compounds 1 and 2 were 1208 and 1543 mAh g–1, respectively, and the second discharge capacities decrease to 735 mAh g–1 for compound 1 and 848 mAh g–1 for compound 2. The irreversible capacities loss is largely ascribed to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. To understand the influence of the conjugation of POMs and Ag-trz complexes on the battery performance, we also tested the electrochemical properties of the (NBu4)3[AsW12O40] as anode materials for LIBs under the identical conditions. And there is a remarkable reduction at the corresponding initial discharge capacities (588 mAh g–1 at the first cycle and 246 mAh g–1 at the second cycle), indicating that AsW12@Ag-trz hybrids are conducive to improving LIBs capacity than that of single component. After a dramatic initial drop, the cycling capacity maintains the levels of ca. 430 mAh g–1 for 100 cycles for 1 (capacity retention of 35.6%) and 480 mAh g–1 for 2 (capacity retention of 31.1%). For (NBu4)3[AsW12O40], the capacity changes to 80 mAh g–1 (capacity retention of 13.6%) after the same 100 cycles. This superior may be attributed to the stabilized crystal structures and the synergistic effects of AsW12 polyoxoanions and Ag-trz complexes. It can be also concluded that the channels facilitate the faster electrochemical insertion/extraction of Li+ ions, leading to a better capacity performances of compound 2. Moreover, the first cycle Coulombic efficiencies (CE) are only 59% for 1 and 52% for 2, maybe due to the electrolyte decomposition and the other side-reaction. But the Coulombic efficiencies of 1 as well as 2 all reach a plateau at ca. 99% after 30 cycles, suggesting their commendable cycling reversibility.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Battery Performance

On the basis of the promising features of compounds 1 and 2 reported in the work, their electrochemical performances as anode materials for LIBs were investigated in detail.  shows the galvanostatic discharging/charging curves of compounds at a current density of 100 mA g-1, and the first discharge capacities of compounds 1 and 2 were 1208 and 1543 mAh g-1, respectively, and the second discharge capacities decrease to 735 mAh g-1 for compound 1 and 848 mAh g-1 for compound 2. The irreversible capacities loss is largely ascribed to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) films. To understand the influence of the conjugation of POMs and Ag-trz complexes on the battery performance, we also tested the electrochemical properties of the (NBu4)3[AsW12O40] as anode materials for LIBs under the identical conditions. And there is a remarkable reduction at the corresponding initial discharge capacities (588 mAh g-1 at the first cycle and 246 mAh g-1 at the second cycle), indicating that AsW12@Ag-trz hybrids are conducive to improving LIBs capacity than that of single component. After a dramatic initial drop, the cycling capacity maintains the levels of ca. 430 mAh g-1 for 100 cycles for 1 (capacity retention of 35.6%) and 480 mAh g-1 for 2 (capacity retention of 31.1%). For (NBu4)3[AsW12O40], the capacity changes to 80 mAh g-1 (capacity retention of 13.6%) after the same 100 cycles. This superior may be attributed to the stabilized crystal structures and the synergistic effects of AsW12 polyoxoanions and Ag-trz complexes. It can be also concluded that the channels facilitate the faster electrochemical insertion/extraction of Li+ ions, leading to a better capacity performances of compound 2. Moreover, the first cycle Coulombic efficiencies (CE) are only 59% for 1 and 52% for 2, maybe due to the electrolyte decomposition and the other side-reaction. But the Coulombic efficiencies of 1 as well as 2 all reach a plateau at ca. 99% after 30 cycles, suggesting their commendable cycling reversibility.
